batchSend.title: Batch Send Settings
batchSend.frequencyHint: Supported range: 1-1,000,000 packets/sec, ensure sufficient system performance for high frequencies
batchSend.isolateInterface: Isolate Interface (interface won't handle other network traffic during sending)
batchSend.isolateDescription: When enabled, temporarily disconnects normal network connection on this interface, only used for sending test packets, automatically recovers after completion
batchSend.adminRequired: Administrator privileges required for this feature
batchSend.macosCommand: macOS users please start with the following command:
batchSend.windowsInstruction: Windows users please right-click the application and select "Run as administrator"
batchSend.linuxCommand: Linux users please start with the following command:
batchSend.isolateWarningDev: Development Mode: Interface isolation feature will be simulated, won't actually affect network connections. This is only for testing UI and business logic.
batchSend.isolateWarning: Warning: When interface isolation is enabled, this interface will temporarily be unable to perform normal network communication. If this is your primary network connection, it may affect network access.
batchSend.isolateStatusDev: Development Mode Interface Isolation: Simulating isolation state for interface {interface}
batchSend.isolateStatus: Interface Isolation Mode: Interface {interface} temporarily disconnected from normal network
batchSend.isolateRecoveredDev: Development Mode: Interface {interface} simulation recovery completed
batchSend.isolateRecovered: Interface {interface} automatically restored to normal network connection
batchSend.taskStarted: Batch send task submitted, frequency: {frequency} packets/sec

fields.dst_mac: Physical address of the destination device to identify packet receiver. Format: 6 hex numbers separated by colons, e.g., AA:BB:CC:DD:EE:FF
fields.src_mac: Physical address of the source device to identify packet sender. Automatically filled with selected interface's MAC address
fields.ether_type: Ethernet type field identifying upper layer protocol. 0800 for IPv4, 0806 for ARP
fields.version: IP protocol version number. Fixed at 4 for IPv4, indicating 4th version of Internet Protocol
fields.ihl: Internet Header Length in 4-byte units. Standard IPv4 header is 20 bytes, corresponding to value 5
fields.tos: Type of Service field specifying packet priority and QoS requirements. Usually set to 0 for normal service
fields.total_length: Total length of IP datagram in bytes, including IP header and data. Set to 0 for automatic calculation
fields.identification: Identification field uniquely identifying all fragments of a datagram for reassembly. Usually set to 0 for system assignment
fields.flags: Flags field controlling fragmentation behavior. 2 means Don't Fragment, 0 means fragmentation allowed
fields.fragment_offset: Fragment offset field indicating position of current fragment in original datagram. Set to 0 when not fragmenting
fields.ttl: Time To Live, maximum number of routers packet can pass through. Decremented by 1 at each router, discarded when 0
fields.protocol: Protocol field identifying upper layer protocol type in IP datagram. 1=ICMP, 6=TCP, 17=UDP
fields.header_checksum: IP header checksum for detecting transmission errors in IP header. Set to 0 for automatic calculation
fields.srcIp: Source IP address identifying packet sender. Automatically filled with selected interface's IP address
fields.dstIp: Destination IP address identifying packet receiver. Fill with target host's IP address
fields.srcPort: Source port number identifying sender application port. Range 0-65535, usually use ports above 1024
fields.dstPort: Destination port number identifying receiver application port. e.g., HTTP=80, HTTPS=443, SSH=22
fields.seq: Sequence number for data ordering and retransmission in TCP connection. Initial sequence number when establishing connection
fields.ack: Acknowledgment number indicating next expected sequence number. Only valid when ACK flag is set to 1
fields.data_offset: Data offset, TCP header length in 4-byte units. Standard TCP header is 20 bytes, corresponding to value 5
fields.reserved: Reserved field, must be set to 0. Field reserved for future TCP protocol extensions
fields.flag_urg: Urgent flag. When set to 1, urgent pointer field is valid and packet should be processed with priority
fields.flag_ack: Acknowledgment flag. When set to 1, acknowledgment number field is valid for confirming received data
fields.flag_psh: Push flag. When set to 1, requires immediate push of data to application without buffering
fields.flag_rst: Reset flag. When set to 1, indicates serious connection error requiring connection reset
fields.flag_syn: Synchronize flag. When set to 1, requests connection establishment for TCP three-way handshake
fields.flag_fin: Finish flag. When set to 1, sender has no more data to send and requests connection closure
fields.window_size: Window size indicating number of data bytes receiver can accept, used for flow control
fields.checksum: TCP checksum for detecting transmission errors in TCP header and data. Set to 0 for automatic calculation
fields.urgent_pointer: Urgent pointer indicating position of urgent data when URG flag is 1. Usually set to 0
fields.length: UDP length, total length of UDP header and data in bytes. Set to 0 for automatic calculation
fields.hwType: Hardware type identifying data link layer protocol. 1 indicates Ethernet
fields.protoType: Protocol type identifying network layer protocol. 0800 indicates IPv4 protocol
fields.opcode: Operation code identifying ARP operation type. 1=ARP request, 2=ARP reply
fields.srcMac: Sender MAC address, hardware address of sender in ARP message
fields.dstMac: Target MAC address, hardware address of target in ARP message. Usually all zeros in requests
fields.data: Payload data section. TCP/UDP protocols support both text and hexadecimal formats, other protocols only support hexadecimal
